text:
*[Bug 18464] merge's sort=FALSE argument still sort's by NA*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18464>

Heather Turner (<mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |ht@heatherturner.net

--- Comment #7 from Heather Turner (<mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>) ---
This bug report can be closed, since `merge()` is working as documented: first
"The rows in the two data frames that match on the specified columns are
extracted, and joined together."; then "If all.x is true, all the non matching
cases of x are appended to the result as well, with NA filled in the
corresponding columns of y"; then `sort` defines "Should the result be sorted
on the by columns?".

text:
*[Bug 18782] seq.POSIXt can return POSIXct objects with integer storage type*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18782>

--- Comment #4 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
(In reply to Michael Chirico from comment #3)
I agree that the inconsistency between .Date  and .POSIXt  is not good
but I still maintain that coercion to double should not happen unnecessarily,
notably because integers store more efficiently  and hence e.g.  `+` and `-`
also do not unnecessarily coerce to double.

I'd be happy to change (the title of) this PR into
   "seq.Date always coerces its result to double type"  and would confirm the
report then.
